comments.commentBody:
"Trump Reassures the Media (For Now)"

The media may be reassured. I'm not. Not even "for now".
Thank you, NY Times, for your integrity. Can we keep our Union strong as we go through these confusing and frightening times? Yes we can. With a muffled press? Not so much.

I invite my fellow readers to appreciate the genius in the Hiroko Masuike photo composition accompanying this article.

Looking on from the portraits we see over the left shoulder of our soon to be President none other than Jimmy Carter as Trump's better angel. I imagine him whispering in Donald's ear:
"Donald you will never forgive yourself if you do not govern for all of the people and disavow racism once and for all"

Smiling smugly and perched over his right shoulder is Andrew Carnegie tempting him: "Trump. They're all out to get you. Stick it to 'em"

Behind the president elect is none other than the halo of FDR talking directly to the American people (bypassing the MSM) during one of his weekly fireside tweets. Er... chats.
comments.userLocation: I'm out in the woods. i akuhambi kahle emahlathini

comments.commentBody: Please, once more, stop using the benign term "alt right"! Follow NPR's lead. Do not soft-pedal a racist, neo-Nazi group by adopting its self-serving label. Haven''t you learned yet?

Hillary has been hounded an persecuted. Believe me. The judiciary would prosecute so if there were any case. This whole nothing burger served to cast aspersions on an honorable person who didn't really use email, but was running for office as a Democrat. She preferred face-to-face communication and secure diplomatic pouches. Her email account was set up by State IT security experts who visited the basement where the computer was housed. She used her own domain, as she had as a senator. The email address was obviously not one from the State Department. Why did it take four years to notice if any damage could have been done? Classified information varies by government agency, and might be accidentally sent to unclassified servers. Information gets classified retroactively. One is innocent until proven guilty in our system.
Wikipedia has more information as does Political Magazine whose author read the FBI reports. The State rulebook requires three printouts (and filing) of each email received. Rather absurd and dated. The computer system at State was out-dated and staff wasn't always able to print out emails. Secretary Clinton worked from pointed data. With adequate funding (tax money), State IT can be updated and technology from a decade ago used to ensure that emails are backed up incrementally on a nightly basis. No need to print and file each email, which I doubt anyone who needed to function had time to do.

Please look at the person Trump appointed to head the EPA. This person is known for his anti-global warming position.
Watch the needs.

Suddenly Trump is becoming more and more "POLITICALLY CORRECT!"
Too hilarious, LOL.

Don't let Trump off the hook, not even once. That's my advice. People with his personality disorder need to be confronted firmly and shown they are not going to get their way.

Call him out on every lie, every distraction, every bit of fudged information, every flip-flop ond things he's "vowed" to do. Please!
Trump in full "manic mode"! Or is it his ADD? Either way, the man needs help.

Magicians call this misdirection. The meetings......the tweets........the reversal of policy, are all meant to distract. The real issue to watch out for is Trumps intermingling of his finances with the US government, which will forever be untraceable and confused.

Mr. Trump knows enough, now that he's won the election and sees that a lot of what is in front of him is way over his head, not to continue pursuing the Roy Cohn methodology of demoralizing and continuously attacking even if what comes out of his mouth is the farthest thing from the truth.  But let's see how long this lasts. Someone is bound to upset or cross him in the following months.

Nope, Trump is a demagogue through and through.  He is not only amoral, he simply doesn't care what is right or wrong, true or false.  He's a salesman who would sell his mother for a dime.  There's no depth to be found here.  He is simply that.
Or he is just playing to those that sit in front of him . . . at the moment.
Um, yes, because that is all part of the show. "Care" is not something he cares about.
Trojan horse. All the guys lined up behind Trump now currently laughing at the entire country and how easy this was to pull off.
You got it all figured out, Rohit! Good job! Gold star!
I'm fine with two out of three.
Left Coaster: sorry, but focusing on wages is now entirely a luxury. Trump & Co. have moved us way, way past that. The entire dialogue around notions of "country", "republic" is now in play.

Is anyone surprised? Can the NYTimes please stop reporting on this meeting and focus instead on the fact that a number of prominent data scientists are calling for recounts of votes in three swing states because of alleged fraud? Let's get the word out and focus on the issues that might actually impact the future of our country.

Oh, how richly ironic it is Hillary's supporters who refuse to accept the results of the election. What happened to the sanctity of our democratic institutions, the peaceful transition of power, etc.? You do realize, of course, that she has already conceded the election?

The protests are not based on "refusal to accept the results of the election." Protesters are expressing their disapproval of Trump's policies as expressed at his rallies, his appointments to key positions.
Dave, you do realize that HRC won the election. Unfortunately (understatement of the century), Trump got the job, but he didn't win the vote.

It is not anarchy to stand up for that which is right, in defense of our democratic ideals.  Mel, you are jousting at windmills if you are naive enough to believe Trump's actions as president will be in the peoples' best interests!
That's a very interesting analysis with the ring of ominous truth.

It is well known that Trump, a con man who knows little about actual policy, frequently will parrot whatever views were expressed by the last person he spoke with about an issue. So, the fact that Trump, after he spoke with General Mattis, sounded less excited about bringing back torture than he has in the past means very little, as Trump will almost certainly go back to his pro-torture views once he speaks with one of the many right wing crazies that he is filling his Administration with.

This editorial is certainly correct that it is "alarming to confront how thinly thought through many of the president-elect's stances actually are." It would have been nice, however, if the New York Times and the rest of the media had spent time and resources during the campaign focusing on the fact that Trump is a complete empty suit when it comes to policy, and contrasting that with the comprehensive and sensible policy agenda laid out by Hillary Clinton who was undoubtedly a real expert when it came to the government decisions that actually impact our lives. But, instead, you folks at the Times (and most of the rest of the media) focused incessantly on Clinton's perfectly legal use of a private email server, pretending that that was somehow equivalent to the fact that Trump is a dangerous, corrupt, and bigoted con man who is woefully unprepared to be President.

https://www.facebook.com/WinningProgressive

Good points; however, I respectfully submit that you missed the obvious lesson from the election. Trump won by speaking to, and getting out the vote of, that segment of the population not swayed by rational pieces in the NYT or any other members of the "elite media."

Trump is masterful when telling his target audience what it wants to hear. Not surprisingly, the NYT was pleased to hear Trump declare that it "is a jewel," after all those present are human.

The NYT is, and likely will be, the newspaper of record, regardless of what Trump says. It is critical to maintain your high standards. An excellent start would be the flagrant conflict of interest that Trump pretends to be oblivious to. Trump isn't stupid, he knows exactly what he serves his interest. And don't forget his tax returns.

"Any barely objective observer who didn't already realize it during the campaign would certainly not be swayed by yet more evidence of Trump's complete vacuity."

You're right. Now how do we fix this? How can we change this?

Well said, WP.
Many were the days when I searched in vain for coverage of Clinton's campaign, but found only headlines on Trump Trump Trump Trump Trump...
Even after your endorsement of Hilary Clinton, articles discussing her abilities and policies were impossible to find.
No thanks to journalism in the US did Hilary Clinton win the popular vote.

Many of us are just concerned about how much damage can be done by one man at the top appointing far-right politicians to the highest positions in the time that he manages to stay in power. Inevitably he'll be taken down for sheer nonsensical rhetoric and decision-making and there will be a President Pence.

How long will it take to undo the damage of this appointment by the people? It's difficult not to be very concerned for Americans and The World Community.

Here's a revelation: Trump has discovered that if you act like a raving lunatic, people will give you far too much credit when you pull back a bit and say something normal. We've seen several pundits lead with this "Wait a minute--maybe Trump won't be so bad after all" revelation. They're so desperate to find a silver lining that a glint of tin foil from a madman's hat will do.

It's foolish to think that there's anything normal about Donald Trump. His wild flip-flopping and unpredictability doesn't make him more presidential. It makes him more dangerous. It means that he doesn't have a consistent worldview or a moral center. It means we should worry about the alt-right zealots that surround him, and who will be telling him what he thinks. And we need to remember who hand picked the zealots.

It doesn't help that a few so-called "honorable" Republicans are being tapped to work for a man that they once found repugnant. People like Ryan and Romney revealed much about their character when they endorsed the 2012 Republican platform, which was little more than Trumpism with Febreze.

It's little comfort that the much-maligned Democrats will still be here to rescue us from yet another destructive, expensive and retrograde Republican presidency. As long as Trump doesn't do more damage that mere mortals can undo, we'll prosper again. Maybe we'll levy a tax on everyone who voted for Trump. That seems fair.

"(t)he glint of tin foil from a madman's hat..."
Perfect.
Trump keeps getting graded on a curve and getting a gold star for doing what normal people do just because they are normal

Aye, Gemli, and nothing will be quite worth fighting for, or believe anymore.  Early at dawn, a choice was made by this American to send greetings to my Country men, women and children to count blessings on the biggest celebration of our Nation, Thanksgiving:  Baptists, Catholics, Jewish, Muslims, Non-Believers, Protestants, All Americans from across the borders.  Wishes for beautiful flowers to place on their table, but watching the Statue of Liberty in the midst of this greeting, rise silently holding the Torch of Freedom, my eyes grew misty and there was a slight chill in the air.

The problem with this movie is that it is bad. BP looks as if he is on a time out. Apparently he was...because never has he ever been less charismatic and luckily for him had this been his first film he would be done as an actor. She is radiant and carrying teh entire film as far as wattage. Ms Cotillard but one feels bad for her as if she is hostage to an other sure fire big budget money maker. One wonders if his personal life bled disastrously into every day of shooting. My money says it did.  Mr. Zemeckis missed by a wide margin here but I am impressed by how hard it is for people to say teh emperor is naked or dull and disappointing. By teh way if a female director had made this she would be done forever. This is a fine lesson of never hire a star who is being tortured at home.
Thanks for the heads up.  And did Scott write "neither ..... or ...."  I always thought it was neither red nor blue, for example.

And all the metaphors and food comparisons! Say what something is without comparing it to something else. There's style, and then there's actual writing. Though the canoe comment was genius, it only almost makes up for the rest of it. And now I want to listen to that Talking Heads song, "Life During Wartime."
RDC, the, not teh (x3). There are other problems with your writing, but I don't have time right now to list them.
